questions.text: A term neonate is being evaluated for altered level of consciousness. There are also decreased spontaneous movements and abnormal respiration on examination prompting the suspicion for Intraventricular hemorrhage. Which of the following is the investigation of choice?
questions.solution:
Cranial Ultrasonography is the preferred modality for diagnosis of intraventricular hemorrhage (IVH) because of the high sensitivity, ease of access and lack of radiation exposure. 

The most important risk factor for intraventricular hemorrhage (IVH) is prematurity with high incidence in very low birth weight (VLBW) infants weighing <1500 g at birth. The risk of GMH-IVH increases with decreasing gestational age and birth weight. Some other risk factors that increase its incidence include respiratory distress, mechanical ventilation, cardiopulmonary resuscitation and hypotension.

The origin of bleeding is the small blood vessels in the germinal matrix, located between the caudate nucleus and the thalamus at the level of the foramen of Monro. In preterm infants, a weak structural support system makes the germinal matrix vulnerable to hemorrhage and injury particularly when there is hemodynamic instability.

 Most cases present on the first day of life and the majority in the first few days of life. The most common presentation is a stuttering course with altered levels of consciousness, respiratory cycle alterations, hypotonia, decreased spontaneous and elicited movements, and subtle changes in eye position and movement. Catastrophic deterioration occurs in very few patients with seizures, coma and decerebrate posturing progressing over minutes to hours. Some patients may have a clinically silent presentation.

Ultrasound is the preferred modality because of the high sensitivity, ease of access and lack of radiation exposure. Routine ultrasound screening is recommended for infants born at < 28 weeks gestation. CT scan is useful to detect cortical neuronal injury and Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) is used to evaluate any hypoxic ischemic brain injury.

questions.text: Investigation of choice to diagnose congenital adrenal hyperplasia due to 21-hydroxylase deficiency is estimation of ____________ levels.
questions.solution:
17-hydroxyprogesterone levels estimation is the investigation of choice to diagnose CAH due to 21 hydroxylase deficiency. It will be markedly elevated.

Congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH)/adrenogenital syndrome is a family of autosomal-recessive disorders associated with the diminished synthesis of cortisol and aldosterone. The most common cause of ambiguous genitalia in a newborn is a classic 21-hydroxylase deficiency.

Virilization is usually apparent at birth in females and within 2 to 3 years of life in males. 

Severe 21-hydroxylase deficiency presents with symptoms including weight loss, dehydration, weakness, hypotension, and electrolyte imbalances. Accumulated steroid precursors like 17-hydroxyprogesterone, are shunted into the pathway of androgen synthesis leading to elevated levels of androstenedione and testosterone. This can result in abnormal genital development in affected female fetuses during early gestation. 

Females may have masculinized external genitalia. This can include enlargement of the clitoris, partial or complete labial fusion, and a shared opening of the vagina and urethra (urogenital sinus). 

Untreated individuals develop signs of androgen excess after birth.  These signs include accelerated skeletal maturation, premature epiphyseal closure leading to stunted adult stature, excessive muscular development, the appearance of pubic and axillary hair, acne, and deepening of the voice. In males, enlargement of the penis, scrotum, and prostate. In females, the clitoris may become further enlarged. 

Other findings include:

  1. Elevated androstenedione and testosterone (in females).
  2. Low cortisol and aldosterone.
  3. Elevated ACTH levels.

questions.text: A 50-year-old smoker presented with miosis, ptosis of the right eye, and anhidrosis of the right side of the face. He also has occasional chest pain along with fever and weight loss for the past month. A pancoast tumour is suspected. Which of the following is the investigation of choice for this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical picture is suggestive of a Pancoast tumor (superior sulcus tumor) and the investigation of choice is MRI.

Investigations in Pancoast tumor:

  • MRI (MRI > CT) is the investigation of choice for superior sulcus tumor/ Pancoast tumor as the associated soft tissue infiltration, the extent of which can be best visualized using an MRI.
  • FDG-PET scan shows high uptake by the tumor cells. FDG is taken up by all metabolizing cells but more avidly by cancer cells.
  • Bronchoscopy can be done in endobronchial tumors to obtain a tissue diagnosis.

Pancoast syndrome/ superior sulcus tumor results from a local extension of a tumor growing in the apex of the lung, with the involvement of C8, T1, and T2 nerve roots, stellate ganglion, and the chest wall.

It presents with pain that radiates to the ulnar distribution of the arm, often with the destruction of the 1st and 2nd ribs.

Patients with the central or endobronchial growth of the primary tumor may present with a cough, hemoptysis, wheeze, stridor, dyspnea, or post-obstructive pneumonitis.

Regional spread can cause

  • Tracheal obstruction
  • Esophageal compression with dysphagia
  • Recurrent laryngeal paralysis with hoarseness
  • Phrenic nerve palsy with the elevation of the hemidiaphragm and dyspnea
  • Sympathetic nerve paralysis with Horner’s syndrome (enophthalmos, ptosis, miosis, and anhydrosis)

The below images show chest x-ray, FDG-PET images, and management of the Pancoast tumor.

questions.text: A child presented with bilateral proptosis. He is suspected of having chloroma based on his peripheral smear. What is the next investigation of choice?
questions.solution:
The next investigation of choice, in a child suspected to have a chloroma, is a bone marrow biopsy.

Chloroma, also called myeloid sarcoma, granulocytic sarcoma, or myeloblastoma is an extramedullary tumor that occurs in 2% to 14% of patients with acute myeloid leukemia (AML). Frequent sites of involvement are the skin, lymph nodes, gastrointestinal tract, bone, soft tissue, testis, and peritoneum.

Isolated orbital involvement of myeloid sarcoma is rare. Proptosis is the most common presentation. Other symptoms include lacrimal swelling, conjunctival mass lesion, retinal hemorrhages, ptosis, dystopia. Decreased visual acuity and ocular movement restriction have also been reported.

Most cases of chloroma can be diagnosed on peripheral smear examination, which is easily available and is relatively inexpensive. Sometimes it may not be associated with any peripheral smear abnormality, and hence bone marrow aspirate and biopsy should be done to confirm AML. The diagnosis can also be made if Auer rods are detected. Myeloid sarcomas have immunophenotypic features that are identical to AML.

Although myeloid sarcomas are radiosensitive, they are managed with systemic chemotherapy in most cases, even in the absence of bone marrow involvement. Surgery and/or radiation therapy may be indicated for symptomatic lesions or tumors causing local organ dysfunction or obstruction.

The image shows Auer rods contained within myeloblasts.

questions.text:
A 36-year-old man presents with a painless testicular mass with a sense of heaviness in the scrotum. His blood work showed raised LDH and AFP. Which of the following is the diagnostic investigation of choice?

LDH - Lactate dehydrogenase.

AFP - α-fetoprotein.
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a middle-aged man presenting with a painless testicular mass with a sense of heaviness in the scrotum suggests the diagnosis of a testicular tumour. Blood work showed raised LDH and AFP which are tumour markers for non-seminomatous germ cell tumours (NSGCTs). The diagnostic investigation of choice is ultrasonography.

Testicular tumours are uncommon male malignancies. Seminomas generally occur in the 4th decade of life, while NSGCTs are common in the 3rd decade of life. Spermatocytic seminomas occur commonly in men older than 50 years. WHO classification of testicular tumours is given below.

Clinical features of testicular tumours are:

  • Occurrence in the specific age group.
  • Painless testicular mass is the usual symptom
  • Sense of scrotal heaviness
  • Abdominal or lumbar mass due to metastasis
  • Chest pain, dyspnea, and haemoptysis due to lung metastasis
  • Prepubertal interstitial cell tumours produce androgens, causing precocious puberty
  • Postpubertal interstitial cell tumours produce feminising hormones, leading to gynecomastia, erectile dysfunction, loss of libido and azoospermia.

The diagnostic investigation of choice is ultrasonography (USG). USG of the affected as well as the unaffected testis is done and is mandatory. Tumour markers aid in the diagnosis. Chest X-ray is done to detect 'cannon ball' metastasis in the lungs.

Other options:

Option A - Contrast-Enhanced Computed Tomography (CECT) is done to assess the thoracic, abdominal and pelvic areas for metastasis. Although it is essential in staging and monitoring response to therapy it is not the diagnostic investigation of choice.

Option C: Trans-scrotal biopsy has no role in the diagnosis of testicular tumours.

Option D: Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) may be used as an adjunct if ultrasound findings are equivocal, or if the location of the mass is uncertain.

questions.text: What is the investigation of choice for the diagnosis of kala-azar?
questions.solution:
The rapid dipstick test is the method of choice for the diagnosis of kala-azar.

The following tests are used for the laboratory diagnosis of kala-azar:

  • Rapid diagnostic tests - rK39 and dipstick test strip.
  • Parasitological diagnosis - demonstration of LD bodies on microscopy is confirmatory
  • Surveillance purposes - Aldehyde test of Napier
  • Serological diagnosis - Rapid dipstick test, direct agglutination test, ELISA, indirect fluorescent antibody test
  • Assessing immune status - Leishmanin (Montenegro) test 
    • Induration of ≥ 5 mm is considered positive
    • Usually becomes positive 4-6 weeks after onset of cutaneous leishmaniasis

questions.text: A 32-year-old man presents with severe pulsatile proptosis, chemosis, diplopia, and an orbital bruit in the left eye, three weeks following a motor vehicle accident. He also reports headaches and tinnitus on the left side. Intraocular pressure in the left eye is elevated. What is the investigation of choice for this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a patient with pulsatile proptosis, chemosis, and a bruit is suggestive of a traumatic carotid-cavernous fistula. Selective catheter digital subtraction angiography is the investigation of choice.

A carotid cavernous fistula is an arteriovenous fistula communicating between the internal carotid artery and the cavernous sinus.
Causes: 

  • Severe head trauma (most common in males) 
  • Degenerative vessels (atheromatous or syphilitic disease) without discoverable trauma, especially in women

Types: 

  1. Direct fistula: 
    • High-flow shunts in which carotid artery blood passes directly into the cavernous sinus through a defect in the wall of the intracavernous portion of the internal carotid artery 
  2. Indirect fistula 
    • Dural shunt/ low flow shunt in which the arterial blood flows through the meningeal branches of the external or internal carotid arteries indirectly into the cavernous sinus. Clinical manifestations are subtler than in a direct fistula.

It presents within days or weeks following trauma; usually ipsilateral to the fistula but may be bilateral, or even contralateral. The classical triad of presentation is pulsatile proptosis, chemosis, and bruit. Other features include:

  • Marked epibulbar vascular dilatation - “Corkscrew vessels”
  • Chemosis
  • Pulsatile proptosis associated with a bruit and a thrill
  • Increased IOP
  • Anterior segment ischemia, characterized by corneal epithelial edema, aqueous cells, and flare and in severe cases iris atrophy, cataract, and rubeosis iridis.
  • Ophthalmoplegia (III-VI nerve palsies)
  • Ophthalmoscopy findings: optic disc swelling, venous dilatation, intraretinal hemorrhage from venous stasis, and impaired retinal blood flow.
  • Visual loss
    • Immediate - due to ocular or optic nerve damage
    • Delayed - as a result of exposure keratopathy, secondary glaucoma, central retinal vein occlusion, anterior segment ischemia, or ischaemic optic neuropathy.

Investigations:

  • Selective catheter Digital subtraction angiography is the investigation of choice.
  • CT and MRI angiography can also be done

Treatment is mostly conservative. Embolization during arteriography is the treatment of choice.

questions.text: A 52-year-old female presents with gradually worsening shortness of breath over the past 6 months. She is on methotrexate for rheumatoid arthritis, and interstitial lung disease is suspected. What is the investigation of choice to confirm the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
High-resolution CT is the investigation of choice for ILD.  

Interstitial lung disease (ILD) refers to the remodeling of interstitial space, the region between the epithelium and endothelium. The main pathology is fibrosis.

It can be broadly classified into:

  •  ILD of known causes like occupational(coal workers' pneumoconiosis, silicosis), rheumatological(rheumatoid arthritis, diffuse>limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis, polymyositis, dermatomyositis, and occasionally SLE and Sjogren syndrome), and treatment-induced.
  • ILD of unknown cause, which is also called idiopathic interstitial pneumonia (IIP). 
IIP is further divided into:
  • Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (IPF)/ Usual Interstitial Pneumonia (UIP): It is the most common form of idiopathic interstitial pneumonia.
  • Non-specific interstitial pneumonia (NSIP)
  • Cryptogenic Organizing pneumonia (COP)
  • Acute interstitial pneumonia (AIP)
  • Respiratory bronchiolitis associated ILD (RB-ILD)
  • Desquamative interstitial pneumonia (DIP)
  • Lymphocytic interstitial pneumonia (LIP)
  • ILD is a restrictive lung disease with low V/Q mismatch where the alveolar-arterial oxygen gradient (a-A O2 gradient) is increased due to a defect in diffusion resulting in hypoxemia.

ILD(pulmonary fibrosis) is the most serious adverse effect of prolonged amiodarone (class iii antiarrhythmic) use. Thus, amiodarone is contraindicated in ILD patients.

questions.text: A patient presented with a high fever, altered sensorium, headache, neck rigidity, and seizures. He was diagnosed with HSV encephalitis. Which of the following tests can be used to confirm the diagnosis?

choices.text: CSF culture on chick embryo lines

questions.solution:
HSV-DNA demonstration in CSF by PCR is the investigation of choice for HSV encephalitis. 

Herpes simplex virus (HSV) encephalitis is defined as inflammation of brain parenchyma caused by the herpes virus, and it typically presents as an acute febrile illness.

Patients typically present with acute onset of fever, altered levels of consciousness, personality changes, and evidence of either focal or diffuse neurologic signs and symptoms, especially in the temporal lobe. Focal or generalized seizures occur in many patients with HSV encephalitis. Other most commonly encountered focal findings include aphasia, ataxia, upper motor neuron or lower motor neuron type lesions, and cranial nerve deficits.

HSV-DNA demonstration in CSF by PCR is the investigation of choice for HSV encephalitis. Other investigations that can help include CSF examination, CSF culture, serological studies, MRI, CT, EEG, and brain biopsy.

The T2-weighted MRI of the brain will show hyperintensity in the temporal lobe in most of the patients. Bilateral involvement of the temporal lobe is more common in HSV encephalitis.

The image below is a coronal T2-weighted MR image showing a high signal intensity in the temporal lobes in a patient with HSV encephalitis.

Management includes supportive therapy (monitoring of intracranial pressure, fluid restriction, avoidance of hypotonic IV fluids), anticonvulsants for seizures, and intravenous acyclovir is beneficial in the treatment of HSV encephalitis.

 Other options:

Option A: IgM antibodies in CSF - Serological tests to detect antibodies are used for primary herpes infections.

Option B: Tzanck smear of CSF - A positive smear shows multinucleated giant cells with faceted nuclei and ground glass appearance. It is a rapid, inexpensive, and fairly sensitive diagnostic test. The Tzanck smear is typically used to diagnose cutaneous herpes infections, such as herpes simplex or varicella-zoster virus. It is not an appropriate diagnostic test for HSV encephalitis, as it does not provide definitive confirmation of the presence of HSV in the CSF.

Option D: CSF culture in chick embryos - It is not a sensitive test used for the diagnosis of HSV encephalitis. Negative CSF viral cultures have no value in ruling out HSV encephalitis. Although this method can be used to isolate HSV, it is not as sensitive or specific as PCR for viral DNA and it can take a longer time to obtain results.

questions.text: A neonate is brought on the 5th day of life with abdominal distension. The mother informs that the child has not passed meconium yet. Distal bowel obstruction is suspected. What is the diagnostic test of choice?
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation (abdominal distension and failure to pass meconium) is suggestive of Hirschsprung’s disease. Contrast enema is used as the initial investigation when Hirschsprung’s disease is suspected and is the diagnostic test of choice. Rectal biopsy is the gold standard investigation.

Hirschsprung disease or congenital aganglionic colon is characterized by the absence of ganglion cells in the myenteric (Auerbach) plexus and submucosal (Meissner) plexus of the distal intestinal segment. This is because of the premature arrest of normal migration of neural crest cells from the cecum to the rectum.

It causes a muscular spasm of the distal intestinal segment, resulting in functional obstruction of the affected bowel and proximal dilation (megacolon). The area between the dilated and contracted segments is referred to as the transition zone.

Hirschsprung disease is classified into -

  • Short-segment - limited to the rectosigmoid segment
  • Long-segment - proximal extension beyond the rectosigmoid segment

Note: while the gold standard investigation for Hirschsprung’s disease is rectal suction biopsy, an imaging study will first be required to figure out the location from where the sample needs to be taken.

The image below shows dilated ganglionic and contracted aganglionic segments in Hirschsprung's disease,

It is more common in males. Most infants present with abdominal distension and bilious vomiting with failure to pass meconium within the first 24 hours of life. Enterocolitis is a potentially fatal complication.

Water-soluble contrast enema is the initial investigation. It shows a narrow aganglionic segment, a conical transition zone, and a dilated proximal bowel. It helps in excluding other causes of distal intestinal obstruction, such as colonic atresia, meconium ileus, and meconium plug syndrome. It is both diagnostic and therapeutic for the latter.

questions.text: A male patient comes to the outpatient clinic with dilated tortuous veins in his lower limb. Varicose veins is suspected. Which of the following is the investigation of choice for this condition?
questions.solution:
Duplex ultrasound is the investigation of choice for varicose veins.

Varicose veins refer to subcutaneous dilated veins of more than 3 mm in diameter. 

Investigations : 

  • Clinical examination
  • Venous duplex ultrasound which tells about:
    • The site of reflux
    • Size of vein
    • Location of perforators
    • Presence of obstruction in the deep venous system
    • Indication of pelvic source of reflux or obstruction
  • MR venography
  • Invasive procedures such as contrast venography or intravenous ultrasound.

Management of varicose veins

Incompetence Management
Great saphenous vein (GSV) and saphenofemoral (SFJ) 
  • Endothermal ablation (gold standard treatment for varicose veins). It includes:
  • Endovenous laser ablation (EVLA)
  • Radiofrequency ablation (RFA)
  • Trendelenburg procedure (Flush Ligation of Saphenofemoral Junction (SFJ) after ligation of 6 tributaries) ± stripping (retrogradely up to the knee, to prevent saphenous nerve injury.)     
Short saphenous vein (SSJ) and saphenopopliteal (SPJ)
  • Flush ligation of SPJ (Stripping is not done to prevent sural nerve injury)
  • Endothermal ablation:
  • Endovenous laser ablation (EVLA)
  • Radiofrequency ablation (RFA)
Perforator 
  • Dodd and Crockett surgery - Multiple subfascial ligations
  • Subfascial endoscopic perforator surgery (SEPS) - smaller incision, so cosmetically better
  • Endothermal ablation:
  • Endovenous laser ablation (EVLA)
  • Radiofrequency ablation (RFA)

New treatment modalities:

  • Foam sclerotherapy - The Tessari method is a widely used method to prepare foam for sclerotherapy. Sclerosant: air ratio taken is 1:3 or 1:4.
  • Endovenous glue therapy - endoluminal application of cyanoacrylate adhesive 
  • TriVex - Transilluminated powered phlebectomy

questions.text: An 8-year-old boy with persistent diurnal incontinence and abdominal distention is being evaluated for a posterior urethral valve. What is the investigation of choice for this condition?
questions.solution:
Voiding cystourethrogram (VCUG) is the investigation of choice for a posterior urethral valve.

Posterior urethral valves (PUV) are obstructing membranous folds within the lumen of the posterior urethra, which hinders the outflow of urine from the urinary bladder and may precipitate chronic renal disease in children.

It occurs due to disruption of normal embryonic development of the male urethra between the 9th and 14th weeks of intrauterine life, resulting in the formation of membranous folds within the lumen of the posterior urethra.

Children with PUV who are not diagnosed before birth may present with delayed voiding or a poor urinary stream. Infants are predisposed to repeated urinary tract infections (UTIs). Other common signs and symptoms may include a palpable abdominal mass, failure to thrive, lethargy, poor feeding, urosepsis, and urinary ascites. Older boys may have persistent diurnal incontinence or abdominal distention. Physical examination in the newborn typically discloses a palpable walnut-sized bladder, which corresponds to the hypertrophic detrusor muscle.

Other options:

Option A: Trans-rectal ultrasound scan (TRUS) is usually performed in conjunction with a biopsy of the prostate in male patients with an abnormal digital rectal examination of the prostate

Option B: Renal nuclear scintigraphy with a technetium-99m-labelled dimercaptosuccinic acid can be used to visualise any abnormality or thinning of the renal parenchyma, like renal scarring

Option D: A Non-contrast CT scan is the investigation of choice in a patient with suspected urinary tract calculi

questions.text: A 45-year-old obese male with a history of alcohol use presents to the emergency department with severe abdominal pain radiating to the back. Blood tests reveal elevated serum amylase and lipase levels. What is the investigation of choice for this patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation of the patient is suggestive of acute pancreatitis. Contrast-enhanced computed tomography (CECT) is the imaging investigation of choice. 

Acute pancreatitis is a condition characterized by inflammatory damage to the pancreas. Various causes of acute pancreatitis are:

  • Gallstone-induced (most common cause)
  • Alcohol (2nd most common cause)
  • Trauma (most common cause in children)
  • Iatrogenic- Post-endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP)
  • Drug-induced pancreatitis (Thiazides, Azathioprine, Anti-cancer drugs, etc)
  • Hypertriglyceridemia
  • Hypercalcemia
  • Scorpion bite
  • Idiopathic

Clinical presentation of acute pancreatitis is characterized by epigastric pain radiating to the back which is relieved by bending forward, nausea, and vomiting. Acute hemorrhagic pancreatitis can present with certain named signs like:

  • Fox sign: Discoloration in the inguinal region
  • Bryant’s sign: Discoloration on the scrotum
  • Cullen’s sign: Discoloration around the umbilicus
  • Grey Turner’s sign: Discoloration in the flanks

Blood investigations show increased serum amylase and lipase levels. Serum lipase is more sensitive and specific than serum amylase but it rises late. USG cannot help establish the diagnosis of pancreatitis. Plain erect chest x-ray and abdominal radiographs are not diagnostic of acute pancreatitis and can only be used to rule out certain differentials. Contrast-enhanced computed tomography (CECT) is the imaging investigation of choice, but may not always be needed. Various scoring systems are used to grade the severity of acute pancreatitis based on blood investigations and radiographic findings.

questions.text: The radiological imaging of choice for pheochromocytoma is ___
questions.solution:
MRI is the investigation of choice for localizing the tumor in pheochromocytoma.

Pheochromocytoma is a catecholamine-secreting tumor derived from the chromaffin cells of the adrenal medulla. 

Clinical features of pheochromocytoma are due to the autonomic effects of excess epinephrine and norepinephrine. 

  • Weight loss is due to the increase in catecholamines which increase basal metabolism.
  • Pallor is due to alpha 1-mediated vasoconstriction. 
  • Abdominal pain with nausea and vomiting is commonly seen.

Diagnosis of pheochromocytoma requires biochemical testing followed by imaging.

  • Urinary and plasma levels of catecholamines and metanephrines 
  • MRI is the investigation of choice for localizing the tumor 
  • MIBG Scintigraphy and PET Scans like Ga- DOTATE, DOPA- or FDG- PET can be used for extra-adrenal tumors and metastases

Treatment of pheochromocytoma:

Surgical resection of the tumor is the definitive treatment. Preoperatively, an alpha-receptor blocker (phenoxybenzamine) is given to control the effects produced by excess catecholamines. Beta-blockers are used to control tachycardia after adequate alpha blockade is achieved. This is to prevent unrestricted alpha-mediated vasoconstriction.

Following surgery, yearly follow-ups lifelong should be done.

questions.text: Which of the following is the initial investigation of choice in a 14-year-old girl who has not attained menarche?
questions.solution:
Pelvic ultrasonography is the initial investigation of choice in suspected primary amenorrhea, to determine the presence of the vagina, uterus, tubes and ovaries. 

Primary amenorrhea is defined as the absence of menstruation by 14 years without the development of secondary sexual characteristics or by 16 years regardless of the presence of secondary sexual characteristics.

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy presents with a white pupillary reflex, for which enucleation was performed. Histopathological examination of the specimen revealed Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes. What is the investigation of choice for staging his condition?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis with a histopathological finding of Flexner Winterstein rosettes in a 7-year-old child with a whitish pupillary reflex is retinoblastoma. MRI is considered to be the investigation of choice in the pretreatment staging of retinoblastoma.

Retinoblastoma is a malignant proliferation of immature retinal neural cells and is the most common intraocular malignancy in children. It is associated with mutations in the RB1 gene at chromosome 13q14. It is a tumour of a group called small round blue cell tumours because the immature retinal neural cells are seen as small round cells with large nuclei. 

White pupillary reflex or leukocoria is the most common presenting feature, followed by a squint which is usually convergent. Rarely, the child may present with nystagmus and defective vision.

Image showing leukocoria of left eye

 

Histopathology of the tumor shows small round cells with large nuclei. Microscopic features of a well-differentiated tumor include Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes (highly specific of retinoblastoma), Homer-Wright rosettes, pseudorosettes, and fleurettes formation. Areas of necrosis and calcification can also be seen. Flexner Wintersteiner rosettes refer to an arrangement of columnar cells around a central lumen, which is highly characteristic of retinoblastoma.

The histopathological image of retinoblastoma is shown below.

 
USG, CT and MRI are the mainstay for imaging of retinoblastoma. MRI is the most sensitive technique for evaluating tumor infiltration of the optic nerve, extraocular extension and intracranial disease.
 
Treatment typically involves chemotherapy plus focal therapy. The commonly used three-drug regimen is the CVE regimen consisting of Vincristine, Carboplatin, Etoposide. Focal therapy includes cryotherapy, laser photocoagulation, thermotherapy, plaque radiotherapy, and external beam radiotherapy.
Enucleation is done when
  • the tumor involves more than half of the retina
  • the optic nerve is involved
  • glaucoma is present and the anterior chamber is involved

In the stage of extraocular extension, the globe bursts through the sclera, usually near the limbus or near the optic disc. This is followed by rapid fungation and involvement of extraocular tissues results in marked proptosis. Distant metastasis occurs through the lymphatic spread and the direct extension by continuity to the optic nerve and brain.

questions.text:
An 18-year-old male presents to the emergency department with epistaxis and a nasal mass. What is the investigation of choice to evaluate his condition?

Contrast-Enhanced Computed Tomography - (CECT)  

Paranasal Sinuses - (PNS) 

Magnetic Resonance Imaging - (MRI)
questions.solution:
History of nasal mass and associated epistaxis in an 18-year-old raises the suspicion of nasopharyngeal angiofibroma. CECT of the PNS and nose can be done to evaluate the patient.

CECT of the PNS and nose is particularly useful for revealing characteristic findings such as the anterior bowing of the posterior wall of the maxillary sinus, known as the Antral sign or Holman-Miller sign (shown in the image below), which is indicative of nasopharyngeal angiofibroma.

Nasopharyngeal angiofibroma is a benign but locally invasive tumor that predominantly affects adolescent males aged 10-20 years. It typically originates from the posterior part of the nasal cavity near the superior margin of the sphenopalatine foramen and is thought to be testosterone-dependent. Clinically, this condition presents with profuse, recurrent spontaneous epistaxis, progressive nasal obstruction, conductive hearing loss, and otitis media with effusion. It may also cause additional features such as proptosis, cheek swelling, and broadening of the nasal bridge.

Diagnosis is primarily based on clinical presentation, with CECT serving as the preferred imaging technique to confirm the diagnosis and assess the extent of the tumor. Carotid angiography may be performed to evaluate the vascularity of the tumor and its feeding vessels, typically arising from the external carotid artery, and potentially from the internal carotid system in cases of larger tumors with intracranial extension. Biopsy of the mass is generally avoided due to the risk of severe bleeding.

Staging of juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma

Stage Spread
IA Limited to the nose and/or nasopharynx
IB Extension into ≥ one paranasal sinus
IIA Minimal extension into the sphenopalatine foramen with minimal part of pterygopalatine fossa
IIB Full occupation of pterygopalatine fossa with Holman-Miller sign, may with erosion of orbital bones
IIC Extension into the cheek, temporal fossa, or posterior to pterygoids through the pterygomaxillary fossa
IIIA Erosion of skull base with minimal intracranial
IIIB Erosion of skull base with extensive intracranial with or without cavernous sinus

Surgery is the treatment of choice. Embolization of the vessels can be done prior to surgery to reduce the risk of bleeding during the surgery. Radiotherapy, chemotherapy, and hormonal therapy can also be considered.

questions.text: Which of the following is considered the investigation of choice for the evaluation of a patient with suspected peptic ulceration?
questions.solution:
Gastroduodenoscopy is considered the investigation of choice for the evaluation of a patient with suspected peptic ulcer disease.

Gastroduodenoscopy helps to directly visualise the ulcer and simultaneously perform a biopsy to rule out malignancy. This makes it a better investigation compared to others.

Gastric peptic ulcers are predominantly located along the lesser curvature near the interface of the body and antrum. The most common site of peptic ulcer is the anterior wall of the proximal duodenum, within a few centimeters of the pyloric valve. 

The image below shows a peptic ulcer with a round to oval and sharply punched-out defect, and a clean mucosal margin.

Complications of peptic ulcers:

  • Bleeding - It is the most common complication of posterior duodenal ulcer.
  • Perforation - It is the most common complication of anterior duodenal ulcer and gastric ulcer.
  • Obstruction.
  • Hour-glass deformity of the stomach - Large long-standing gastric ulcers can lead to fibrosis. Fibrosis if present can cause hourglass constriction of the stomach. Barium meal shows double pouched stomach.
  • Tea-pot deformity (handbag stomach) - It is caused by cicatrization and shortening of the lesser curvature.
  • An ulcer can erode posteriorly into the pancreas and anteriorly into the liver.
  • Malignancy.

questions.text: The radiological investigation of choice for avascular necrosis of bone is ________
questions.solution:
The investigation of choice for avascular necrosis of bone is MRI as initially, bone infarction occurs in the marrow.

Avascular necrosis or osteonecrosis is a painful bone condition resulting from diminished blood supply mainly due to trauma or non-traumatic etiologies. 

The typical features are pain with movements in or near the joint, click in the joint, joint stiffness, limping gait, and deformity. Restriction of actions is also a feature of this condition.

The radiograph shows reactive new bone formation, increased radiolucency in the subchondral bone, and a distorted articular surface. MRI has high sensitivity and specificity in diagnosis.

Management in the early stages can involve osteotomy while in late stages pain control, splinting, arthrodesis and total or partial replacement are preferred.

questions.text: What is the investigation of choice for neurosyphilis?

choices.text: FTA-ABS- Fluorescent Treponemal Antibody Absorption test

questions.solution:
The investigation of choice for neurosyphilis is VDRL.

The CSF-VDRL test is highly specific and, when reactive, is considered diagnostic of neurosyphilis.

Involvement of the CNS in syphilis is detected by examination of CSF for:

  • Mononuclear pleocytosis (>5 white blood cells/μL).
  • Increased protein concentration (>45 mg/dL).
  • CSF VDRL reactivity.

Other options :

Option B: Fluorescent treponemal antibody absorption test (FTA-ABS) is a sensitive test for syphilis, detecting specific antibodies to Treponema pallidum. While it can remain positive for life, even after treatment, it is less specific for active neurosyphilis compared to the VDRL test, which is why it is not the first-line test for this condition.

Option C: Rapid plasma reagin Test (RPR) is another non-treponemal test like the VDRL, but it is performed on serum, not CSF. It is used for diagnosing syphilis in the bloodstream and monitoring treatment response, but it cannot specifically diagnose neurosyphilis. Thus, it is not the preferred investigation for central nervous system involvement.

Option D: Treponema pallidum immobilization test (TPI) is an older, treponemal test once used for detecting syphilis. Due to its complex and labor-intensive nature, it has been largely replaced by more efficient and widely available tests like the FTA-ABS. Given its outdated status, the TPI test is rarely utilized in modern clinical practice and is no longer recommended for diagnosing neurosyphilis.
